February 1927.THIS Report gives a summary of the recently published returns of unemployment in the various industries. In Table. (A) is shown the course of unemployment during February, while Table (B.) on p. 2 gives an analysis, of the number of persons on the registers of Employment Exchanges in Great Britain at the 28th February, 1927.(A.) February is normally a month in which seasonal improvement in industry takes place, but last month's reduction in unemployment was more than twice as great as that which took place during February of last year. Whilst the numbers on the registers are still appreciably higher than at this time last year, it is interesting to note that the number of women unemployed is now less than, it was a year ago;. This is doubtless largely accounted for by the improvement in the textile trades." It is particularly noteworthy that in no insured industry has there been an increase in unemployment of 2,000 or over.The improvement has been most marked in building and cotton. In the former trade the reduction in unemployment was largely seasonal in nature, but part of it was doubtless brought about by the increasing availability of cou-structional material. The increase in activity in cotton was most in. evidence amongst firms in the weaving departments, largely as the result of the demand of some of the chief Indian markets. The position in the American spinning section, however, also showed some improvement, whilst it is reported that in the Egyptian section practically full-time running continued. In shipbuilding, engineering and other allied industries unemployment continued to remain severe, notwithstanding the fact that some further improvement took place during the month. It is noteworthy, however, that at the end of the month there were more blast furnaces in operation than at the end of February last year, whilst the output of pig-iron and steel, despite the shorter month, was greater than during January. The improvement in tailoring shows that the seasonal recovery in this trade has begun to set in.Very little change took place in coal mining; in Durham and Wales appreciable numbers of men remain unemployed.(D.) Latest Figures.The latest figure of unemployment published is that for the 14th March, giving the total number on the registers as 1,118,700.
